[[38th G8 summit]] }} '''Camp David''' is the country retreat for the [[president of the United States]]. It is located in the wooded hills of [[Catoctin Mountain Park]] near [[Thurmont, Maryland]], and [[Emmitsburg, Maryland]], about 62 miles (100 km) north-northwest of [[Washington, D.C.]]"[http://www.nps.gov/pwr/customcf/apps/maps/showmap.cfm?alphacode=cato&parkname=Catoctin%20Mountain%20Park Park Map Viewer]". [[Catoctin Mountain Park]]. Retrieved on February 4, 2011."[http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/MapItDrawServlet?geo_id=16000US2477825&_bucket_id=50&tree_id=420&context=saff&_lang=en&_sse=on Thurmont town, Maryland]". [[United States Census Bureau]]. Retrieved on February 4, 2011."[http://www.nps.gov/cato/faqs.htm Frequently Asked Questions]". [[Catoctin Mountain Park]], Retrieved on February 4, 2011. "10. Where is Camp David? The Presidential Retreat is within the park however, it is not open to the public and its location is not shown on our park maps for both security and privacy. If you're interested in historical information, visit our Presidential Retreat webpage." It is officially known as the '''Naval Support Facility Thurmont''', because it is technically a military installation, the staffing is primarily provided by the [[Seabees]], [[Civil Engineer Corps]] (CEC), and the [[United States Navy]] and the [[United States Marine Corps]]. Naval construction battalions are tasked with base construction and send detachments as needed. Originally known as Hi-Catoctin, Camp David was built as a camp for federal government agents and their families by the [[Works Progress Administration]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.archives.gov/publications/prologue/2008/winter/camp-david.html|title=Camp David|date=2016-08-15|website=National Archives|language=en|access-date=2019-10-09}} Construction started in 1935 and was completed in 1938.{{cite web | title =12 WPA Projects that Still Exist | publisher =[[How Stuff Works]] | url =http://people.howstuffworks.com/12-wpa-projects-that-still-exist.htm | access-date =March 11, 2009}} In 1942, [[Franklin D. Roosevelt|President Franklin D. Roosevelt]] converted it to a presidential retreat and renamed it "'''Shangri-La'''" (for the [[Shangri-La|fictional Himalayan paradise]] in the 1933 novel ''[[Lost Horizon]]'' by British author [[James Hilton (novelist)|James Hilton]]). Camp David received its present name from [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]], in honor of his father, and [[David Eisenhower|grandson]], both named David.{{cite book |last=Eisenhower |first=David |author2=Julie Nixon Eisenhower |title=Going Home to Glory: A Memoir of Life with Dwight David Eisenhower, 1961–1969 |url=https://archive.org/details/goinghometoglory00davi_0 |url-access=registration |publisher=Simon and Schuster |location=New York |year=2010 |page=[https://archive.org/details/goinghometoglory00davi_0/page/31 31]}} The Catoctin Mountain Park does not indicate the location of Camp David on park maps due to privacy and security concerns, although it can be seen through the use of publicly accessible satellite images. ==Presidential use== Franklin D. Roosevelt hosted [[Winston Churchill|Sir Winston Churchill]] in May 1943.{{cite web |url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/about/camp_david/ |title=Camp David |publisher=[[White House|Whitehouse.gov]] |access-date=June 29, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090630021056/http://www.whitehouse.gov/about/camp_david/# |archive-date=June 30, 2009 |url-status=dead |df=mdy-all }} [[Dwight Eisenhower]] held his first cabinet meeting there on November 22, 1955 following hospitalization and convalescence he required after a heart attack suffered in Denver, Colorado on September 24.{{cite web|url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/?pid=10363|title=Dwight D. Eisenhower: Message Prepared for the Conference on Fitness of American Youth.|publisher=}} Eisenhower met there with [[Nikita Khrushchev]] for two days of discussions in September 1959.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=epHiDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA115&lpg=PA115&dq=%22Kennedy+often+allowed+White+House+staff+and+Cabinet+members+to+use+the+retreat+when+he+or+his+family+were+not+there.%22&source=bl&ots=FjIa7bHL2A&sig=ACfU3U2Jr8PmGnhQRo7DaXkSzICU-5u2Yg&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwj64NaarI7lAhVYrJ4KHSFgA6MQ6AEwCXoECAwQAQ#v=onepage&q=%22Kennedy%20often%20allowed%20White%20House%20staff%20and%20Cabinet%20members%20to%20use%20the%20retreat%20when%20he%20or%20his%20family%20were%20not%20there.%22&f=false|title=Continuity of Government: How the U.S. Government Functions After All Hell Breaks Loose|last=Campbell|first=Douglas E.|date=2016-12-27|publisher=Lulu.com|year=|isbn=9781365614422|location=|pages=115|language=en}}{{self-published source|date=February 2020}}{{self-published inline|date=February 2020}} [[John F. Kennedy]] and his family often enjoyed riding and other recreational activities there, and Kennedy often allowed [[White House]] staff and Cabinet members to use the retreat when he or his family were not there. [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] met with advisors in this setting and hosted both [[Prime Minister of Australia|Australian prime minister]] [[Harold Holt]] and [[Prime Minister of Canada|Canadian prime minister]] [[Lester B. Pearson]] there.{{cite web|url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/?pid=28308|title=272 - Address at the State Department's Foreign Policy Conference for Educators.|date=June 19, 1967|work=The American Presidency Project}} [[Richard Nixon]] was a frequent visitor. He personally directed the construction of a swimming pool and other improvements to Aspen Lodge.W. Dale Nelson, ''The President is at Camp David'' (Syracuse University Press, 1995), pp. 69-94. [[Gerald Ford]] often rode his snowmobile around Camp David and hosted [[President of Indonesia|Indonesian president]] [[Suharto]] there.{{cite web|url=http://www.infoplease.com/spot/campdavid1.html |title=Camp David: A History of the Presidential Retreat |publisher=Infoplease.com |date=July 18, 1942 |access-date=June 29, 2009}} [[Jimmy Carter]] initially favored closing Camp David in order to save money. Once Carter actually visited the place, he decided to keep it.{{Cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=266&dat=19770822&id=2d0wAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_dwFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1091,5150913&hl=en|title=Kentucky New Era - Google News Archive Search|website=news.google.com|access-date=2019-10-09}} Carter brokered the [[Camp David Accords]] there in September 1978 between [[President of Egypt|Egyptian president]] [[Anwar Sadat|Anwar al-Sadat]] and [[Prime Minister of Israel|Israeli prime minister]] [[Menachem Begin]]. [[Ronald Reagan]] visited the retreat more than any other president. In 1984, Reagan hosted [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|British prime minister]] [[Margaret Thatcher]]. [[George H. W. Bush]]'s daughter, [[Dorothy Bush Koch]], was married there in 1992, in the first ever wedding held at Camp David.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/06/28/us/bush-s-daughter-marries-with-a-minimum-of-fuss.html|title=Bush's Daughter Marries With 'a Minimum of Fuss'|date=June 28, 1992|work=The New York Times}} During [[Bill Clinton]]'s time in office, British prime minister [[Tony Blair]] was among the many visitors that the president hosted at Camp David.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/983641588|title=CONTINUITY OF GOVERNMENT : how the u.s. government functions after all hell breaks loose.|last=E.|first=CAMPBELL, DOUGLAS|date=2016|publisher=LULU COM|isbn=9781365614422|location=[S.l.]|oclc=983641588}}{{self-published source|date=February 2020}}{{self-published inline|date=February 2020}} He also held the [[2000 Camp David Summit]] between [[2000 Camp David Summit|Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak and Palestinian Authority chairman Yasser Arafat.]]{{Cite web|url=https://2001-2009.state.gov/p/nea/rls/22698.htm|title=Trilateral Statement on the Middle East Peace Summit at Camp David|last=Department Of State. The Office of Electronic Information|first=Bureau of Public Affairs|website=2001-2009.state.gov|language=en|access-date=2019-10-09}} [[George W. Bush]] hosted dignitaries, including [[President of Russia]] [[Vladimir Putin]], there in 2003,{{cite news |title=With issues to resolve, Bush welcomes Putin to Camp David |date=September 27, 2003 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/09/27/world/with-issues-to-resolve-bush-welcomes-putin-to-camp-david.html |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=August 6, 2011 |first=David |last=Sanger }}{{cite web |url=http://www.losthorizon.org/found/CampDavid |title=Camp David}} and hosted British prime minister [[Gordon Brown]], in 2007.{{cite news |title=Brown to meet Bush at Camp David |date=July 26, 2007 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/6917760.stm |work=[[BBC News Online]] |access-date=August 6, 2011 }} He also hosted [[Prime Minister of Denmark|Danish prime minister]] [[Anders Fogh Rasmussen]] in June 2006,{{Cite web|url=https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2006/04/20060421.html|title=President Bush to Host Danish Prime Minister Anders Fogh Rasmussen at Camp David|website=georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov|access-date=2019-10-09}} and President [[Musharraf]] of [[Pakistan]] at Camp David.{{Cite web|url=https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2003/06/20030624-3.html|title=President Bush Welcomes President Musharraf to Camp David|website=georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov|access-date=2019-10-09}} [[Barack Obama]] chose Camp David to host the [[38th G8 summit]] in 2012.{{cite web |title=White House moves G8 summit from Chicago to Camp David |url=http://chicago.cbslocal.com/2012/03/05/g8-summit-moved-to-camp-david/ |work=CBS Chicago |publisher=CBS Chicago |access-date=May 18, 2012 |date=March 5, 2012 }} President Obama also hosted [[Prime Minister of Russia|Russian prime minister]] [[Dmitry Medvedev]] at Camp David,{{cite web |title=US hopes Assad can be eased aut with Russia's aid |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/27/world/middleeast/us-seeks-russias-help-in-removing-assad-in-syria.html |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=May 27, 2012 }} as well as the [[Gulf Cooperation Council|GCC]] Summit there in 2015.{{cite web|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2015/04/17/statement-press-secretary-united-states-gcc-summit|title=Statement by the Press Secretary on the United States-GCC Summit|date=April 17, 2015|publisher=}} [[Donald Trump]] hosted congressional leaders at Camp David as Republicans prepared to defend both houses of Congress in the 2018 midterm elections.{{Cite web|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/administration/366656-trump-to-host-congressional-leaders-at-camp-david|title=Trump to host congressional leaders at Camp David|last=Manchester|first=Julia|date=2017-12-28|website=TheHill|language=en|access-date=2019-01-08}} The [[46th G7 summit]] will be held at Camp David June 10–12, 2020..{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2019/12/03/politics/trump-g7-camp-david/index.html|title=Trump announces G7 to be hosted at Camp David after Doral reversal|author=Malloy, Camp David is the light circle to the north.]] On July 2, 2011, an [[McDonnell Douglas F-15 Eagle|F-15]] intercepted a small two-seat passenger plane flying near Camp David, when [[Barack Obama|President Obama]] was in the residence. The civilian aircraft, which was out of radio communication, was intercepted approximately {{convert|10|km|mi|order=flip|sigfig=1}} from the presidential retreat. The F-15 escorted the aircraft out of the area, and it landed in nearby [[Hagerstown, Maryland]], without incident. The civilian plane's occupants were flying between two Maryland towns and were released without charge.{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/norad-intercepts-aircraft-near-camp-david-where-president-obama-staying-with-family/2011/07/02/AGZWpQvH_story.html |title=NORAD intercepts aircraft near Camp David, where President Obama staying with family |access-date=July 2, 2012 |date= July 2, 2011 |work=[[The Washington Post]]}} On July 10, 2011, an F-15 intercepted another small two-seat passenger plane flying near Camp David when Obama was again in the residence; a total of three planes were intercepted over that July 9 weekend.{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/jet-fighters-intercept-planes-3-times-over-weekend-near-camp-david/2011/07/10/gIQAEzan7H_story.html | title=Jet fighters intercept planes 3 times over weekend near Camp David |work=[[The Washington Post]] | date=July 10, 2011 | access-date=January 26, 2015 | last=Weil | first=Martin}}{{clear}} ==Gallery== Churchill-FDR-Shangri-La-1943.jpg|Franklin D.
